isis.stitle: DT-466E and 530E Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1995) - ELECTRONIC CONTROL SYSTEM DIAGNOSTICS - CIRCUIT FUNCTION AND DIAGNOSTICS - VREF VOLTAGE REFERENCE

svcsubproc.title: CIRCUIT FUNCTIONS
svcsubproc.para: The V Ref circuit is a 5 .5 volt power supply from the ECM that provides power to the three wire engine and vehicle sensors and provides a benchmark or reference voltage for the ECM.

svcsubproc.title: FAULT DETECTION/MANAGEMENT
svcsubproc.para: There is no fault detection specifically for the V Ref signal directly, but if there is a V Ref circuit fault the sensor(s) in the section of the circuit affected may set an out of range high or low code. Multiple high or low codes are usually an indication of a V Ref or in some instances a Signal Ground fault condition.
A V Ref signal shorted to ground will cause the ECM to reset causing either a stumble or no start condition.

svcsubproc.title: FUNCTION
svcsubproc.para: The Electronic Control Module contains a regulated 5 volt DC voltage reference source to power engine and vehicle control sensors. The sensor signals are compared to the Voltage Reference to determine actual sensor output signal values. These values are processed by the ECM for engine operation.

svcsubproc.title: OPERATION
svcsubproc.para: The ECM is supplied with Battery Voltage when the ignition key is ON at terminals 37 and 57. Ground circuits are supplied at terminals 20, 40 and 60. The ECM provides a constant regulated 5 volt reference signal from terminal 26 to supply voltage to engine and vehicle sensors. A return circuit for sensors is supplied at terminal 46.

svcsubproc.title: ECM VOLTAGE REFERENCE DIAGNOSTICS
svcsubproc.para: If multiple sensor codes are set, it is possible that the V REF signal circuit is open or the return signal circuit is open. Follow troubleshooting procedures to determine if V REF circuits are at fault. The engine will not run without a valid V REF signal.
